I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
supplementary  grant  to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Afghanistan  for  the  Regional  Power 
Transmission Interconnection Project.  
 
II.  THE APPROVED PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Rationale 
 
2.  The project is to construct a transmission line between Tajikistan and Afghanistan. The 
objective is to export Tajik  summer electricity surpluses of up to 300 megawatts (MW) to 
Afghanistan, which has an energy deficit. The project was first conceived and approved by the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) in 2006.1  Construction on the Tajik side has progressed well 
and will be completed as scheduled in late 2010, but the construction of the larger portion of the 
project on the Afghan side is behind schedule. The late start-up in construction and later, 
mounting security problems in the project area in 2009 delayed the work and increased costs. A 
funding gap of $12 million needs additional finance. The design, characteristics, and scope of 
the project remain unchanged.    
 
B.  Objectives and Scope 
 
3.  The  project  promotes  regional  cooperation  and  energy  security  in  Afghanistan  and 
export  revenues  for  Tajikistan.  It  reinforces  energy  work  under  the  Central  Asia  Regional 
Economic Cooperation program, and is a means to expand energy security and trade in the 
region. Afghanistan has an energy deficit and Tajikistan a surplus in summer. The operation 
contributes to energy trade in the region and complements another project financed by ADB to 
build a transmission line from Uzbekistan to Afghanistan. The design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1. 
 
C.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan 
 
4.  The  project,  including  taxes,  duties,  and  interest  during  construction,  was  originally 
estimated at $55.5 million (Table 1 and Table A3.1 summarize the original cost and financing 
plan). ADB provided a loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR23,563,000 ($35 million) to 
Afghanistan from its Special Funds resources. Originally, the Afghanistan Reconstruction Trust 
Fund  was  to  provide  $16.5  million  in  cofinancing,  but  was  later  replaced  by  the  Islamic 
Development Bank, which is still a cofinancing partner.  
 
D.  Status of and Progress in Project Implementation 
 
5.  The Afghan portion of the transmission line has two components: (i) an 157-kilometer 
(km) 220-kilovolt transmission line from Sherkan Bandar to Pul-e-Khumri substation, and (ii) two 
substations in Kunduz and Baghlan financed by the Islamic Development Bank. A condition to 
start project implementation was the signing of a power purchasing agreement, as it would have 
been inappropriate and risky to construct a transmission line without a commercial agreement in

2   
place.  Although all the principles behind this agreement had been defined and accepted prior to 
ADB‟s approval of the project, final negotiations between the parties turned out to be much 
slower than expected. The main stumbling block was the price. The agreement was signed only 
on 29 August 2008, after a 15-month impasse that derailed the original implementation plan, a 
problem later compounded by mounting security problems in the Afghan project area and rising 
costs.  On  1  April  2009,  ADB  approved  an  extension  of  the  loan  closing.  Although  the 
transmission line can still be completed in early 2011 to carry summer electricity from Tajikistan, 
the operation urgently needs an additional $12 million. The 117-km line on the Tajik side will be 
completed by the end of 2010. 
 
6.  As of mid-September 2010, project implementation stood at almost 70% completion with 
an elapsed loan period of 133%. The Ministry of Energy and Water, the executing agency, is in 
the process of complying with many of the loan covenants. Full compliance is expected by 
project completion. The latest project performance report is in Supplementary Appendix A.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED SUPPLEMENTARY GRANT  
 
A.  The Cost Overrun 
 
7.  The contractor requires a contract variation to accomplish the line works and meet 
increases in the cost of equipment, labor and materials (Appendix 2). Due diligence by ADB 
missions,2 and discussions with the contractor and the Ministry of Energy and Water suggest 
the contract variation is justified. The overall cost increase is $12 million.  
 
B.  Impact on the Project 
 
8.  The original project remains unchanged, as do its fundamentals. Tajikistan offers to 
Afghanistan power that is significantly less expensive than Afghanistan can currently access.3 If 
the transmission line is not built, Afghanistan will have to pay an additional $15 million for the 
least-cost alternative, and Tajikistan will lose $21 million in annual sales as the country does not 
have alternative uses for the power in the summer and must spill the water without generating 
energy. The project is a win─win situation for both.  
 
C.  Rationale 
 
9.  The policy criteria and eligibility criteria have been met and even with the additional 
financing,  the  approved  project  will  remain  technically  feasible,  economically  viable,  and 
financially sustainable. As the supplementary financing is to support the existing approved 
impact, outcome and output, no new design and monitoring framework has been prepared. The 
framework will be updated when the activities have been confirmed. 
 
D.  Revised Cost Estimates 
 
10.  The total cost of the project will rise to $67.9 million (Appendix 3). Table 1 provides a 
comparison of the original and revised cost estimates.

F.  Remedial Steps and Implementation Arrangements  
 
12.  The implementation period will be extended to 30 June 2011 and the grant closing date 
to 31 December 2011. The contract for the main contractor and the supervising consultant will 
be revised through variation order to accommodate this change. A variation order is appropriate 
due to the “design and build” nature of the original contract which was awarded based on 
estimated  quantities.  The  actual  quantities,  as  confirmed  by  the  approved  design,  have 
increased because of an increase in line length and the need for additional towers per kilometer 
due to the more difficult terrain than originally envisaged. The additional estimates are an 
integral  component  of  the  overall  design  making  separate  procurement  not  feasible.  The

4   
supervising consultant will certify the quality of the works and act as the first clearance point for 
authorizing payments.  
 
13.  ADB Management has, in principle, approved retroactive financing using up to 20% of 
the grant proceeds for eligible expenditures incurred during the period not exceeding 12 months 
prior to signing of the grant agreement. 
 
14.  The original report and recommendation of the President states that the Ministry of 
Energy and Water, as the executing agency, has overall responsibility for implementing the 
project, specifically, mobilizing financing, completing works, testing and commissioning. The 
former  Afghanistan  Electricity  Agency  (DABM),  a  state-owned  enterprise,  was  the 
implementation agency responsible for the operation and maintenance of the project facilities. 
Accordingly, most of the implementation work to date, prior to project facilities completion and 
becoming  operational,  has  been  carried  out  by  the  Ministry  of  Energy  and  Water  as  the 
executing agency. 
 
15.  In September 2009, DABM was liquidated and Afghanistan Electricity Company (DABS) 
was established as the national electricity utility company in Afghanistan with its own statutes, 
business strategy, and mandate. Currently, the government remains the sole shareholder of 
DABS, but the firm has an independent management team. As the assets and liabilities of 
DABM  had  been  transferred  to  DABS,  DABS  became  the  successor  of  DABM  as  the 
implementing agency for the operation and maintenance for project facilities and, in particular, a 
party to the project agreement, subsidiary loan agreement and power purchasing agreement 
(each as defined in the loan agreement dated 20 May 2007). The same terms and conditions 
will apply other than adjustments required to reflect the corporatization of DABM into DABS.  
 
16.  As discussed in the context of the Energy Sector Development Investment Program 
approved in November 2008,4 the liquidation of DABM and establishment of DABS with the 
accompanying  introduction  of  better  operating  practices  and  independence  from  the 
government is an essential first step toward improving the energy sector in Afghanistan. ADB 
has supported the transformation and the investment program envisaged the medium-term 
partnership of ADB, the government, and DABS.  
 
17.  Except  for  the  above  mentioned  changes,  no  other  changes  in  implementation 
arrangements resulting from the proposed supplementary financing are proposed. If the board 
approves the proposed supplementary grant, then changes to the implementation arrangements 
in relation to the original loan (footnote 1) will be made in accordance with ADB procedures. 
 
18.  The  grant  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  the  Loan  Disbursement 
Handbook (2007, revised from time to time). The original loan (footnote 1) will be disbursed on a 
front load basis.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Financial and Economic Benefits 
 
19.  The economic internal rate of return was recalculated and is now 21.8%, compared with 
31.1% in the original report and recommendation of the President. The financial internal rate of 
return  was  recalculated  and  stands  at  9.8%  compared  with  the  original  12.4%.  This  still 
compares favorably to the weighted average cost of capital of 0%. The revised financial and 
economic analysis is in Supplementary Appendix B. 
 
B.  Environment, Resettlement and Indigenous Peoples Safeguards 
 
20.  All safeguard categorizations remain unchanged. There are no pending issues, although 
land acquisition in some sections of the project was delayed.  The matter was resolved and 
payment instructions made. 
  
C.  Risks and Assumptions 
 
21.  Cost risks are to be contained by incorporating clauses fixing the price and delivery 
period clauses in the primary contractor contract. All cost estimates have been validated by 
ADB teams. Security will always remain a risk. The Ministry of Interior will continue to deploy 
personnel  in  the  area.  The  situation  will  be  monitored  closely  by  security  advisors  in  the 
Afghanistan Resident Mission, the contractor and the Ministry of Interior. The project technical 
specifications remain unchanged and do not present a risk. 
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
 
22.  The government and DABS have assured ADB that the implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents.  
 
23.  In addition to the assurances set out in the loan and project agreements of May 2007, 
which will continue to apply, the government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
project, which are set forth in the grant agreement.  
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
24.  I am satisfied that the proposed supplementary grant would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
supplementary grant not exceeding $12,000,000 to the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan from 
ADB‟s Special Funds resources for the Regional Power Transmission Interconnection Project, 
on terms and conditions that are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft 
grant agreement presented to the Board.  
 
 
 
                  Haruhiko Kuroda 
                  President 
 
27 October 2010

ANALYSIS OF COST OVERRUNS 
 
A.  Transmission Line 
 
1.  The procurement approach of the original project was to award a “design and build” 
contract, with bid evaluation based on assumed quantities. The contract allowed payment to the 
contractor to be based on actual quantities built, with unit rates to be escalated in accordance 
with an agreed price escalation formula. The supervision consultant was engaged to help 
monitor  quality  and  calculate  the  assumed  quantities  based  on  line  length  and  estimated 
number of towers.   
 
2.  The quantity of materials on the Afghan portion of the line, the larger share of the 
project, first increased with increases in line length and the number of towers per kilometer. The 
line length increased because a portion of it needed to be rerouted away from a populated area. 
The  quantity  of  materials  per  kilometer  increased  as  the  terrain  was  more  difficult  than 
envisaged.  Unit rates increased based on the contract escalation formula. Due diligence by the 
consultant and ADB confirmed that these increases and changes were reasonable.  
 
3.  The increase in physical works can be summarized in Table A2 in terms of quantity and 
price comparisons between the preliminary and detailed design.
